pages.text: This ritual may be seen as a reflection of Heinrich Kramer's hypocrisy, who himself resorted to the magic of summoning and binding demons within weapons to gain the power to crush his foes. Summoning one of the high demons (perhaps even a demon of pride, who can say?), he imprisoned it within a staff, which later became known as $(l:artifacts/kramers_torch)his Torch$(). The ritual described henceforth should be a close approximation of what Kramer once performed.

As mentioned before, the key feature of this ritual is the mandatory presence of a living, functioning demon within the circle, preferably a high-ranking one (such as one embodying the Deadly Sins). Only their power will suffice to ignite the Torch. Tormented within its prison, turned against its will for years of confinement, the demon will be a source of rage, which Kramer (and many after him) exploited.

pages.title: Performing the Ritual
pages.text: To increase the chances of successfully performing the Torch Ignition ritual, several points must be considered. Firstly, summoning a demon should ideally occur right before the ritual begins - this way, it will not have time to cause much havoc upon realizing its impending fate. Secondly, it is crucial to prepare one of the $(l:rituals/demonology/demonic_imprisonment)demonic imprisonment rituals$() in advance to prevent the demon from escaping the circle.

pages.annotation_line1: Within the circle, place the inert
pages.annotation_line2: branch of Kramer and a demon of any kind!

pages.title: From a Dusty Note
pages.text: ...$(o)he said a demon was needed. I went through hell itself to get this damn branch, and now they expect me to summon a demon? Nonsense, I'll try without it - the infusion should begin regardless, I think the power of this place will suffice to awaken the Torch. The old man said Kramer would demand a soul in exchange for the Torch, and only the power of a demon would satisfy him. Sounds like madness. I think I'll be done by the time he arrives$()...
